item.title: Metric Space
item.description: Abstracting away the basic properties of Euclidean distance in $\R^n$, and most notably preserving the Triangle Inequality, we make the following Definition. A metric on a set $X$ is a function $d:X\times X\to\R_{\geq0}$ such that (Positive-definiteness). For all $x,y\in X$, we have $d(x,y)=0$ iff $x=y$. (Symmetry.) For all $x,y\in X$, we have $d(x,y)=d(y,x)$. ($\Delta$-inequality). For all $x,y,z\in X$, we have $d(x,z)\leq d(x,y)+d(y,z)$. If $d$ is a metric on $X$, we call the pair $\tpl{X,d}$ a metric space.

item.title: Topological Space
item.description: Let $X$ be a set. We would like to formalize a notion of ‘closeness’ between two points without necessarily referring to a specific metric, but rather, via certain subsets of $X$ called open sets. The following definition is motivated by some properties $^\dagger$ of open sets generated by a metric $d$ on $X$, which we now axiomatize. Definition. Let $X$ be a set. A topology on $X$ is a family $\mc{T}\subseteq\pow(X)$, whose elements are called open sets, subject to the following conditions.
